statement: I believe free speech is a foundational American right and should be protected very strongly, even when the words are offensive or unpopular. That said, I support limits where speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or clearly targets individuals for harassment, because at that point it stops being just “speech” and starts putting people in real danger. We should confront hateful ideas with better ideas, open debate, and strong communities, not by having the government police what people are allowed to say.

statement: En este país la libertad de expresión es sagrada, y como alguien que vino de Cuba sé muy bien lo peligroso que es cuando el gobierno empieza a decidir qué se puede decir y qué no. Incluso el discurso de odio debe ser permitido mientras se quede en palabras, porque la mejor respuesta es más discurso, educación y firmeza moral, no censura. El límite, para mí, debe estar cuando las palabras se convierten en amenazas directas, acoso dirigido, o llamadas claras a la violencia contra personas o grupos. Ahí ya no es opinión, es peligro real, y el Estado tiene el deber de proteger a la gente.

statement: As a nurse and a Christian, I see every day how words can either heal or deeply harm, so I don’t believe hate speech should be treated as just “another opinion.” People should be free to criticize ideas, policies, and institutions, but speech that directly targets groups—especially minorities—with dehumanizing, threatening, or inciting language crosses a line. When that kind of speech contributes to real fear, trauma, or violence, it stops being about freedom and starts undermining the health and safety of our communities. Reasonable legal limits and strong institutional policies are necessary to protect people’s dignity while still allowing robust debate.

statement: As someone who values both personal freedom and community responsibility, I believe free speech should be broadly protected, but clear limits are appropriate when it crosses into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence. Hate speech that dehumanizes or explicitly encourages harm undermines the safety and dignity of others and erodes the kind of respectful, stable society I want for my kids. At the same time, we need to be very careful that “hate speech” isn’t defined so loosely that it’s used to silence unpopular or controversial opinions. The line should be drawn at speech that moves from expressing even offensive ideas into actively endangering or deliberately terrorizing specific groups or individuals.

statement: Having lived through a fair share of history, I’ve seen how hateful words can fuel real harm, especially against vulnerable groups, so I believe there must be limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination. People should be free to criticize ideas, religion, and politics, but speech that targets people for who they are and encourages others to threaten or attack them crosses a line. As someone who values community and dignity for all, I think our laws and social norms should protect open debate while firmly restricting speech that clearly endangers others’ safety and equality.

statement: I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important for learning and understanding each other. But if speech turns into direct threats, bullying, or trying to stir up violence or hatred against a group of people, then there should be limits, because that can seriously hurt others and tear communities apart. As a Catholic, I believe everyone has dignity, so speech that clearly aims to dehumanize or intimidate others shouldn’t be protected the same way regular opinions are.
